data.text: tech support threads often consist of relatively short threads of messages

data.title: Edwards (2009) intro to infrastructures special issue in JAIST

data.text: infrastructures cannot really be planned in advance; they must be grown "organically"
Integration across infrastructures is hard because of gateways
innovators spread evenly in any given domain of innovation
the ratio between educational expenditure and lifetime income is constant across innovator cohorts or domains of expertise
not sure how to phrase this yet: innovators self-allocate across domains (even though each has slightly different costs/benefits) to offset costs/benefits of crowding etc
people tend to specialize more over time (especially in areas with deeper knowledge) due to....
innovators all else equal prefer to work in "hot" areas with low learning costs
narrowing expertise reduces innovation growth to the extent that breadth of expertise is important for innovation
1 of 2 key implications from the model: the knowledge transfer coefficient is a central parameter to optimize to retain our ability to innovate
grand challenges in science are increasingly interdisciplinary
Scientists are increasingly older when they win a Nobel prize, and when they get their first PhD
science is increasingly being done in teams
The most breakthrough science is increasingly being done by small teams
While research effort has skyrocketed, research impact has stagnated or declined
the burden of knowledge on innovators and scientists is increasing
